Author: ca333#0118
Content: we do def. include this in the refactoring and general spam-countermeasures - so even if it is being targeted we are confident to optimize the DEX system to be able to handle very high load as aforementioned by jl777

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a nationstate does a petabyte/sec Ddos against all the nodes... well nothing can withstand that, but short of some sustained insane level Ddos, with graceful degradation, things would be slower but not stopped. also, when we add filtering by known pubkeys, that will filter out a lot of spam

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this was the first atomicDEX stress test, it wasnt able to handle the load that was a lot higher than we expected

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: I understand, I just want to get an idea of what is expected as it progresses

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the key is for the load handling to continuously improve and we certainly have a lot of ideas on how to do this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as things progress, this level of traffic will become easy to handle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then a higher level

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: after that, it seems it is ready for mass usage

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: what would you consider mass usage? on par with a typical CEX?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is a typical CEX?

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: suppose one of the more popular ones...with high usage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anything other than the major top CEX level of traffic i dont see any issues with, as the trade volumes are really not that big

Author: jspook16#3059
Content: Copy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we cant have lot of small orders due to blockchain based

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe it is possible to handle binance level trades, but that is not realistic for the blockchains to support, so it seems a moot point. really the load that needs to be able to handle is whatever load the blockchains can handle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and that is much less than the major CEX trade counts

Author: ca333#0118
Content: `what would you consider mass usage?` - being able to handle loads comparable to any CEX BUT with the big diff. that we will be able to scale this up dynamically - so even if the technical limits are reached (e.g. ~65k ports ) a dynamical scaling would allow us to cover hundreds of thousands if not millions of users once the system is near perfection.

Author: ca333#0118
Content: yes - blockchains being a limitation too - agree on that.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 100 swaps per second, per orderbook seems the max the blockchain side can handle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is 6000 users doing a swap per minute (5 to 10 in parallel)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which actually might be a level we touched today!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so when we can handle 6000 users doing 1 swap per minute, that handles the blockchain capacity

Author: ca333#0118
Content: on the other hand your multichain scalability solution could even bring the tech beyond this swap limit at some point in the future

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, a cluster of fungible chains can do 100 tx/sec per chain, but we can isolate the trading of each on in a different netid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which means the 6000 users doing 1 swap per minute, per fungible chain can be handled across the netids

Author: fat3lvis#6079
Content: It seems an average trade time, or network traffic indicator would be helpful right now. As it is we are just trading blindly, not know if there is a technical issue with our swap, or if it is just network saturation

Author: fat3lvis#6079
Content: And is order queueing handled right now? I never waited more than a few minutes today. Would a swap go through eventually or are swaps attempted beyond the network capacity just going nowhere?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once the network got saturated, it is like a door that had too many people trying to use it at once. some made it through, but most were colliding with others trying to get through.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we did not expect 2000 simultaneous swap attempts for this first stress test, but that is what allowed to find where things meltdown first

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: round 2, we will do much better, but it is not easy to reproduce such high levels of activity short of doing a public stress test, so until the next one, we wont know for 100% sure if the improvements are enough

Author: phm87#7395
Content: it is possible to reproduce with neoload but it is a huge work

Content:
Hello,

It would bring to the most crypto users access to this awesome technology.

Author: ca333#0118
Content: Hi @Goku - we are usually very open for all sort of collaborations. Please contact our Chief Strategist @Steve Lee

Content: @ca333 "DEX app itself is very stable - i.e. no crashs" while I haven't had the app outright crash and close itself, I have to basically restart it every time I use it because it seems to be unable to reopen connectivity once I switch away from it. Or even just going back from the order book and trying to open it again. It will go from showing say 7-10 orders to 1 to 'create an order'

Author: ca333#0118
Content: thank you for the info @Patrick Crypto - can you please send me more infos (operating system version, smartphone device and atomicDEX mobile version) - will investigate this and try to reproduce.
